Author: Moderator#9338
Content:
`who controls that address when neither party to the exchange does`
the exchange parties never lose control of their funds until the trade is final. the DEX protocol ("blockchain") handles this in a trustless way.
hence being a trustless p2p crosschain atomic swap technology. 
read https://komodoplatform.com/komodo-and-the-early-pioneers-of-atomic-swaps/

Author: liqdmetal#8650
Content: https://komodoplatform.com/atomic-swaps/

Author: liqdmetal#8650

Author: ca333#0118
Content:
that article is outdated. 
the new xcat procotol is more efficient:
```
1 - Taker Sends <dexfee>
2 - Maker Successfully Sends <makerpayment>
3 - Taker Successfully Sends <takerpayment>
4 - Maker Spends <takerpayment>
5 - Taker Spends <makerpayment>
```

Author: ca333#0118
Content: @gcharang @Daniel CP ^ - we should add a cross ref to the outdated article and highlight that the new protocol is more efficient

Author: ca333#0118
Content:
i recommend this read to understand our procotol - https://github.com/artemii235/developer-docs/blob/8d54af2e5699b1db5d4b80ee971446665e91449e/docs/basic-docs/start-here/core-technology-discussions/atomicdex.md

fyi- xcat just stands for "[x] (=crosschain) [a]tomic [t]rade/[t]ransaction and is a general term - the git URL (protocol_stellar_xlm_to_ethereum_eth.md) you provided relates to a Stellar specific implementation

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: https://github.com/artemii235/developer-docs/blob/8d54af2e5699b1db5d4b80ee971446665e91449e/docs/basic-docs/start-here/core-technology-discussions/atomicdex.md#atomicdex-manages-a-public-trading-profile-for-bob-and-alice

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Maker, on the other hand, stands to lose more. Since Bob did not follow through with his end of the bargain, the AtomicDEX network indicates on his public AtomicDEX trading profile that he failed in a commitment, thus decreasing his profile‚Äôs reputation. If Bob continues this behavior as a habit, he may find it difficult to discover trading partners.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: From later on in the doc as well

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: So long as the frequency of "Bobs" failing is low, the occasional extra <dexfee> paid by an Alice is a minor issue. However, if there is a sudden spike in misbehavior, the AtomicDEX code has in-built contingency plans which can provide refunds to Alice(s).
